content.json:
# Welcome to ReversingLabs for Microsoft Sentinel!

Thank you for activating ReversingLabs' solution for Microsoft Sentinel. In this workbook you will find a summary of the capabilities of ReversingLabs' Microsoft Sentinel content.

Click the "More information" tab to view our offers in the Azure Marketplace.

parameters.name: rl_feed_check
parameters.description: Grabs list of TI sources and checks for a ReversingLabs feed
parameters.query:
ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| where Tags contains "ReversingLabs"
| summarize count()
| extend rl_feed_exists = iff(count_ > 0, "true", "false")
| project rl_feed_exists

parameters.name: analyst_salary
parameters.description: Used to calculate automation savings in $ amount

parameters.name: ti_feed_check
parameters.description: Checks if there are any items in the ThreatIntelligenceIndicators table in the selected workspace
parameters.query:
ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| where TimeGenerated {timerange}
|take 10
| summarize count()
| extend ti_check = iff(count_ > 0, "true", "false")
| project ti_check

parameters.name: ticloud_api_check
ticloud_api_user
parameters.query:
RLTiCloudQuotas_CL
| where eventType_s == "connection_check"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *)
| project RLAPIUser_s

content.json:
# How to use this workbook

This workbook is designed to give you a summary of your Microsoft Sentinel workspace. You'll find details about your implementation of the Threat Intelligence feature and your operations within Microsoft Sentinel. 

Ensure that you set the Subscription and Workspace parameters with values associated with your Microsoft Sentinel workspace.

To hide all informational messages, change the Guide parameter to "No"
# ðŸ”Ž Your Threat Intel Summary
## Threat Intel Executive Summary
**You could be getting more from your Threat Intelligence feeds!**

The ReversingLabs Ransomware Intel Feed injects indicators curated specifically to hunt ransomware. Our indicators are harvested from confirmed malware and vetted for accuracy, enhanced with additional intel, and evaluated for activeness. This provides your Microsoft Sentinel deployment with dynamic CTI to hunt ransomware in every stage of the ransomware lifecycle.

**Unlock the unlimited potential of Microsoft Sentinel with an unmatched high-quality CTI dataset to protect your organization from ransomware**

- <ins>Ransomware Focused Intelligence</ins> - Indicators harvested from the +2.5 million confirmed, unique malware files analyzed every day producing a wealth of ransomware-related datasets.
- <ins>Focus on the Hunt</ins> - All indicators are enriched with metadata from the perceived vulnerability exploitation techniques, eliminating the need for manual technique identification and tagging.
- <ins>Lower Alert Fatigue</ins> - All indicators are strictly vetted and curated to ensure indicators are not only accurate but active within the last 30 days, eliminating false positives.
- <ins>Policy Driven by Intelligence</ins> - With indicators harvested from active, confirmed malware these indicators can be pushed to short-term policy with confidence.

**[Click here to view the ReversingLabs Ransomware Threat Intel Feed in the Azure Marketplace](https://azuremarketplace.microsoft.com/marketplace/apps/reversinglabs1597673283347.rw_feed_offer0?tab=Overview)**

**[Click here for more info on ReversingLabs' Threat Intelligence offerings](https://www.reversinglabs.com/products/file-reputation-service)**
**Thank you for subscribing to the ReversingLabs threat intelligence feed!**

Here's how to get the most benefit out of the feed:

- Enable analytic rules mapping threat intelligence indicators to your data sources
- Deploy playbooks that will automatically enrich your incidents
- Hunt for indicators in your environment

Threat intelligence is information about cyber threats (malware, ransomware, etc.) and threat actors that help identify malicious events. This information can be referred to as indicators of compromise (or IoC). It consists of objects such as IP addresses, file hashes, and URLs which can be used to identify an attack. Threat Feeds and Search/Query APIs automate processing, correlation, analysis, and threat status information gathering to enable orchestration to build the foundation of threat informed defense.

### Indicator quality

Use this table to check the overall quality of your existing threat intel feeds.
* **Active Indicators**: the total number of active indicators
* **Average Tags**: tags help provide add context indicators
* **Average Age**: stale indicators potentially lead to more false positives
* **Uniqueness Percentage**: this metric shows the percetnage of unique indicators in each of your feeds

content.title: Summary of TI Sources
content.noDataMessage: You don't have any TI sources!

content.title: Indicator Quality

tooltipFormat.tooltip: Average count of tags per indicator
Average age of an indicator in the source
{0} of indicators are unique to this feed

content.json: Select a feed from the dropdown and indicator type below to view more details

parameters.name: sourceFeed
parameters.label: Threat Intelligence Feed
parameters.query:
ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| summarize by SourceSystem
| project SourceSystem

content.json: ### Feed indicator summary by type
View a breakdown of your indicators by type below. Clicking on a tile will provide a summary of the indicator type by feed, and trend in newly added indicators over time.

content.query:
ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| where SourceSystem in ({sourceFeed})
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IndicatorId
| where isnotempty(DomainName)
| summarize dcount_=dcount(DomainName)
| project dcount_, IndicatorType="Domain Indicators", indicatorParam="DomainName"

ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| where SourceSystem in ({sourceFeed})
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IndicatorId
| where isnotempty(Url)
| summarize dcount_=dcount(Url)
| project dcount_, IndicatorType="URL Indicators", indicatorParam="Url"

ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| where SourceSystem in ({sourceFeed})
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IndicatorId
| where isnotempty(FileHashValue)
| summarize dcount_=dcount(FileHashValue)
| project dcount_, IndicatorType="FileHash Indicators", indicatorParam="FileHashValue"

ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| where SourceSystem in ({sourceFeed})
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IndicatorId
| where isnotempty(NetworkIP)
| summarize dcount_=dcount(NetworkIP)
| project dcount_, IndicatorType="IP Indicators", indicatorParam="NetworkIP"

ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| where SourceSystem in ({sourceFeed})
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IndicatorId
| where isnotempty(EmailSenderAddress)
| summarize dcount_=dcount(EmailSenderAddress)
| project dcount_, IndicatorType="EmailSenderAddress Indicators", indicatorParam="EmailSenderAddress"

ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| where SourceSystem in ({sourceFeed})
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IndicatorId
| where isnotempty(EmailSubject)
| summarize dcount_=dcount(EmailSubject)
| project dcount_, IndicatorType="EmailSubject Indicators", indicatorParam="EmailSubject"

ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IndicatorId
| where SourceSystem in ({sourceFeed})
| where isnotempty({indicatorParam})
| make-series Trend = dcount({indicatorParam}) default = 0 on TimeGenerated from ago({timerange:seconds}s) to now() step 1d by SourceSystem
| project-away TimeGenerated
| extend FeedName=SourceSystem
| join kind = inner (ThreatIntelligenceIndicator
    | summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IndicatorId
    | where isnotempty({indicatorParam})
    | summarize dcount_=dcount({indicatorParam}) by SourceSystem
    | project FeedName=SourceSystem, dcount_
    ) on FeedName
| project FeedName, Total=dcount_, Trend

content.json:
# You don't have any Threat Intelligence feeds!*

** Based on query of ThreatIntelligenceIndicator table over last 90 days.*

### What is threat intelligence?
Threat intelligence is information about cyber threats (malware, ransomware, etc.) and threat actors that help identify malicious events. This information can be referred to as indicators of compromise (or IoC). It consists of objects such as IP addresses, file hashes, and URLs which can be used to identify an attack. Threat Feeds and Search/Query APIs automate processing, correlation, analysis, and threat status information gathering to enable orchestration to build the foundation of threat informed defense.

### Why implement a threat intelligence feed?

* âœ… **Less false positives:** using threat intelligence feeds with high quality, vetted indicators can help you filter out the noise and identify real threats in your environment.
* âœ… **Informed incident response:** quality threat intelligence feeds will contextualize indicators with information such as malware family and threat type, which allow defenders to quickly develop well-informed response activities. 
* âœ… **Competitive advantage:** Organizations that can effectively use threat intelligence to protect themselves from cyber attacks can gain a competitive advantage in their industry.

### Resources to learn how to get started with threat intelligence in Microsoft Sentinel:
* [Understand threat intelligence in Microsoft Sentinel](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/sentinel/understand-threat-intelligence?WT.mc_id=Portal-fx#adding-threat-indicators-to-azure-sentinel-with-the-threat-intelligence---taxii-data-connector)
* [Connect Microsoft Sentinel to STIX/TAXII threat intelligence feeds](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/sentinel/connect-threat-intelligence-taxii)
* [ReversingLabs - Explainable Threat Intelligence Overview (YouTube)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s0N5oWxZdh4)
* [ReversingLabs - How to evaluate threat intelligence feeds (eBook)](https://www.reversinglabs.com/ebook/how-to-evaluate-threat-intelligence-feeds)

## See what you're misssing:

The tiles below show the total count of common IoC entity types based on the {timerange:label} of security incidents in your Microsoft Sentinel environment.

content.query:
SecurityIncident
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IncidentNumber
| mv-expand AlertIds
| extend AlertId = tostring(AlertIds)
| join (
    SecurityAlert
) on $left.AlertId == $right.SystemAlertId
| mv-expand todynamic(Entities)
| extend entityType = tostring(Entities.Type)
| where entityType in ("file", "url", "ip", "filehash")
| summarize count() by entityType, IncidentNumber
| summarize count() by entityType
content.title: Incidents created with associated entity type

content.json: Set your acceptable false positive ratio percentage here, using a value from 0-100. 20% is used by default.

parameters.name: fpthreshold
parameters.query:
let fpcount = SecurityIncident
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated,*) by IncidentNumber
| mv-expand AlertIds
| extend AlertId = tostring(AlertIds)
| join (
    SecurityAlert
) on $left.AlertId == $right.SystemAlertId
| mv-expand todynamic(Entities)
| where tostring(Entities.Type) in ("ip", "file", "url", "filehash")
| where Status == "Closed"
| where Classification == "FalsePositive" or Classification == "Undetermined"
| distinct IncidentNumber, Classification, tostring(Entities.Type)
| summarize count() by IncidentNumber, Entities_Type
| summarize FalsePositiveCount=count()
| extend joiner = 1;
let tpcount = SecurityIncident
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated,*) by IncidentNumber
| mv-expand AlertIds
| extend AlertId = tostring(AlertIds)
| join (
    SecurityAlert
) on $left.AlertId == $right.SystemAlertId
| mv-expand todynamic(Entities)
| where tostring(Entities.Type) in ("ip", "file", "url", "filehash")
| where Status == "Closed"
| where Classification == "TruePositive"
| distinct IncidentNumber, Classification, tostring(Entities.Type)
| summarize count() by IncidentNumber, Entities_Type
| summarize TruePositiveCount=count()
| extend joiner = 1;
fpcount
| join tpcount on joiner
| extend totalCount = FalsePositiveCount + TruePositiveCount
| extend ratio=(todouble(FalsePositiveCount) / todouble(totalCount))
| project totalCount, ratio
| extend fpthreshold = case(ratio > {threshold}.0 / 100.0, "true", isnan(ratio) == true, "none", "false")
| project fpthreshold

content.query:
let fpcount = SecurityIncident
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated,*) by IncidentNumber
| mv-expand AlertIds
| extend AlertId = tostring(AlertIds)
| join (
    SecurityAlert
) on $left.AlertId == $right.SystemAlertId
| mv-expand todynamic(Entities)
| where Status == "Closed"
| where Classification == "FalsePositive" or Classification == "Undetermined"
| where tostring(Entities.Type) != ""
| distinct IncidentNumber, Classification, tostring(Entities.Type)
| summarize count() by IncidentNumber, Entities_Type
| summarize FalsePositiveCount=count() by Entities_Type
| extend joiner = 1;
let tpcount = SecurityIncident
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated,*) by IncidentNumber
| mv-expand AlertIds
| extend AlertId = tostring(AlertIds)
| join (
    SecurityAlert
) on $left.AlertId == $right.SystemAlertId
| mv-expand todynamic(Entities)
| where Status == "Closed"
| where Classification == "TruePositive"
| where tostring(Entities.Type) != ""
| distinct IncidentNumber, Classification, tostring(Entities.Type)
| summarize count() by IncidentNumber, Entities_Type
| summarize TruePositiveCount=count() by Entities_Type
| extend joiner = 1;
fpcount
| join tpcount on joiner
| extend totalCount = FalsePositiveCount + TruePositiveCount
| extend ratio=(todouble(FalsePositiveCount) / todouble(totalCount))
| project ratio, Entities_Type1
| extend fpthreshold = iff(ratio > 0.2, true, false)
content.title: False positive % of total closed incidents with given entitiy type

content.json:
## The percentage of false positives in the {timerange:label} is greater than {threshold}%!

The precentage of all incidents seen in your environment that also have typical entity types found in  threat intelligence feeds is high. Consider implementing a threat intelligence feed to augment your existing detections and reduce the volume of false positives.

## Nice work! The percentage of false positives seen in the {timerange:label} is lower than {threshold}%!

You can still benefit from the addition of a threat intelligence feed. Check the "More Information" tab to learn more.
## Incidents created from Threat Intelligence indicators

Use this section to see how your threat intelligence feeds impact your Microsoft Sentinel incidents.

* Incidents created from TI indicators by severity - a summary of incidents created from a threat intelligence indicator by severity
* Closed incident classifications by TI feed - view a breakdown of closing classifications (True Positive, Benign Positive, False Positive, Undetermined) by each feed.

content.query:
let AlertIDs = SecurityAlert
| extend Query_ = tostring(parse_json(ExtendedProperties).Query)
| extend OriginalQuery_ = tostring(parse_json(ExtendedProperties).OriginalQuery)
| where Query_ contains "ThreatIntelligenceIndicator" or OriginalQuery_ contains "ThreatIntelligenceIndicator"
| project TimeGenerated, SystemAlertId;
SecurityIncident
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IncidentNumber
| mv-expand AlertIds
| extend AlertIds = tostring(AlertIds)
| join AlertIDs on $left.AlertIds == $right.SystemAlertId
| summarize dcount(IncidentName) by Severity
content.title: Incidents created from TI indicators by severity
Closed incident classifications by TI feed

content.json: # ðŸ“Š Your Operations Summary
## Operations Executive Summary

Resolution of alerts with the help of actionable threat intelligence can improve the speed and accuracy of triage. Below you will find a summary of your environment's incidents and how a ReversingLabs Threat Intel feed combined with the ReversingLabs solution for Microsoft Sentinel can help take your operations to the next level.

### Summary of incidents
This line chart provides a summary of all incidents created over the selected time range, and how many of those incidents where created from Threat Intelligence indicators.


### Operational efficiency summary
See how playbooks from ReversingLabs impact your operational efficiency:

* **No Enrichment**: incidents that have not had any enrichment 
* **Enriched**: incidents that have been enriched with automation
* **Auto-triaged**: incidents that have been automatically worked via automation

content.query:
let AlertIDs = SecurityAlert
| extend Query_ = tostring(parse_json(ExtendedProperties).Query)
| extend OriginalQuery_ = tostring(parse_json(ExtendedProperties).OriginalQuery)
| where Query_ contains "ThreatIntelligenceIndicator" or OriginalQuery_ contains "ThreatIntelligenceIndicator"
| project TimeGenerated, SystemAlertId;
let TIIncidents = SecurityIncident
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IncidentNumber
| mv-expand AlertIds
| extend AlertIds = tostring(AlertIds)
| join AlertIDs on $left.AlertIds == $right.SystemAlertId
| summarize dcount(IncidentName) by bin(TimeGenerated, 1d)
| extend ["Number of incidents"] = dcount_IncidentName
| extend label = "TI"
| project TimeGenerated, ["Number of incidents"], label;
SecurityIncident
| summarize arg_min(TimeGenerated, *) by IncidentName
| summarize count() by bin(TimeGenerated, 1d)
| project TimeGenerated, ["Number of incidents"]=count_
| extend label = "All"
| union TIIncidents
content.title: Summary of Incidents

content.query:
// find all incidents that had a comment with a ReversingLabs playbook
let RLEnrichedIncidents = SecurityIncident
| mv-expand Comments
| extend CommenterName = tostring(parse_json(tostring(Comments.author)).name)
| where CommenterName contains "Comment created from playbook - ReversingLabs"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IncidentName
| summarize count()
| extend type = "Enriched by ReversingLabs";
// find incidents that had a playbook comment, non RL
let enrichedIncidents = SecurityIncident
| mv-expand Comments
| extend CommenterName = tostring(parse_json(tostring(Comments.author)).name)
| where CommenterName == "Comment created from playbook"
| where CommenterName !contains "ReversingLabs"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IncidentName
| summarize count()
| extend type = "Enriched";
// find all incidents closed by a playbook
let autoTriage = SecurityIncident
| where Status == "Closed"
| summarize arg_min(TimeGenerated, *) by IncidentName
| where ModifiedBy contains "Playbook - "
| summarize count()
| extend type = "Auto-triaged";
SecurityIncident
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IncidentName
| where Comments !contains "Comment created from playbook"
| summarize count()
| extend type = "No Enrichment"
| union RLEnrichedIncidents, enrichedIncidents, autoTriage
| project Type=type, ["Total"]=count_
content.title: Operational Efficiency Summary
content.noDataMessage: None of your incidents are currently being enriched!

content.json: ## Time and Cost analysis

The following data is based on average time spent performing manual enrichment lookups compared to a default SOC analyst salary of $90,000 USD defined in the analyst_salary parameter.

* Time saved - the amount of time saved on performing lookups when using a ReversingLabs playbook
* Current cost savings - based on incidents that have been enriched by a ReversingLabs playbook, this is the amount of money you've saved
* Estimated potential cost savings - this is the amount of money you could be saving when performing enrichment lookups on incidents

**NOTE:** if you modified any ReversingLabs playbook names from the default value during solution deployment, you will need to update the KQL query for each tile below.

content.query:
// average time to manually perform a lookup ~2 minutes
let avg_lookup_time = 120;
let avg_playbook_time = 10;
SecurityIncident
| extend CommenterName = tostring(parse_json(tostring(Comments[0].author)).name)
| where CommenterName == "Comment created from playbook - ReversingLabs-EnrichFileHash"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by IncidentName
| summarize count()
| extend manual_time = count_ * avg_lookup_time
| extend auto_time = count_ * avg_playbook_time
| extend time_saved = manual_time - auto_time
| project time_saved
| extend title = "Time saved"

tooltipFormat.tooltip: Assuming average lookup time of 15 seconds
Assuming average lookup time of 15 seconds

content.json:
# More Information

Check out our offerings in the Azure Marketplace! Select an option using the buttons on the right.

# Reversinglabs Ransomware Intel Feed

```
I AM RANSOMWARE

I came in through your redacted and 
I have already communicated to my team that I'm in...  
now I wait.
It could be a day, it could be a month, 
but I am waiting for the moment when we're positioned 
for mass effect. 
The only thing that can stop what's happening is 
if one of my copies gets busted and gives up its code 
and my indicators get put into a list to watch out for.

Not worried about that, ain't too many creating that kind of info...
```

## Threat Actor Overview

Threat actors have significantly increased the complexity of their operations to the point where they're run like a business to ensure efforts are coordinated and efficient. They work tirelessly to create malicious code that hides in plain site and avoids modern detection methods and they're not going to initiate the final phase of attack until they're positioned to maximize their effectiveness.
This provides you with precious time that can be used to seek, identify, and remove ransomware waiting to be detonated.

## Solution Overview

Enter ReversingLabs Ransomware Intel Feed for the Microsoft Sentinel TAXII data connector that injects indicators **curated specifically to hunt ransomware** into your Threat Intelligence blade. Our indicators are harvested from confirmed malware and vetted for accuracy, enhanced with additional intel, and evaluated for activeness. This provides your Microsoft Sentinel deployment with dynamic CTI to hunt ransomware in every stage of the ransomware lifecycle.

**Unlock the unlimited potential of Microsoft Sentinel with an unmatched high-quality CTI dataset to protect your organization from ransomware**
* Ransomware Focused Intelligence - Indicators harvested from the +2.5 million confirmed, unique malware files analyzed every day producing a wealth of ransomware-related datasets.
* Focus on the Hunt - All indicators are enriched with metadata from the perceived vulnerability exploitation techniques, eliminating the need for manual technique identification and tagging.
* Lower Alert Fatigue - All indicators are strictly vetted and curated to ensure indicators are not only accurate but active within the last 30 days, eliminating false positives.
* Policy Driven by Intelligence - With indicators harvested from active, confirmed malware these indicators can be pushed to short-term policy with confidence.

### View the ReversingLabs Ransomware Intel Feed in the Azure Marketplace here: [LINK](https://azuremarketplace.microsoft.com/marketplace/apps/reversinglabs1597673283347.rw_feed_offer0?tab=Overview)

# TitaniumCloud API

TitaniumCloud is a threat intelligence solution providing up-to-date file reputation services, threat classification and rich context on over 10 billion goodware and malware files. Files are processed using ReversingLabs [File Decomposition Technology](https://www.reversinglabs.com/technology/active-file-decomposition). A powerful set of REST API query and feed functions deliver targeted file and malware intelligence for threat identification, analysis, intelligence development, and threat hunting services.


## OVERVIEW

TitaniumCloud Reputation Services are powerful threat intelligence solutions with up-to-date, threat classification and rich context on over 10 billion goodware and malware files. ReversingLabs does not depend on crowd-sourced collection, but instead curates the harvesting of files from software vendors and diverse malware sources. All files are processed using unique ReversingLabs File Decomposition Technology, combined with other dynamic and detection information, to provide industry reputation consensus. TitaniumCloud supports a powerful set of REST API query and feed functions that deliver targeted file and malware intelligence for threat identification, analysis, intelligence development, and hunting.

## Global File Reputation

TitaniumCloud continually processes goodware and malware files providing early intelligence about attacks before they infiltrate customer infrastructures. This visibility to threats â€œin-the-wildâ€ enables preparation for new attacks and quickly identifies the threat levels of new files as they arrive. TitaniumCloud enables more effective and efficient file analysis, development of better threat intelligence, and implementation of proactive threat hunting programs.

## Contact us to learn more about TitaniumCloud: [LINK](https://www.reversinglabs.com/contact-us)
# â˜ï¸ TitaniumCloud API Usage
Use this tab to monitor your TitaniumCloud API usage. To check your current usage, click the "Check quotas" button below and refresh the page.

armActionContext.title: Check quota
armActionContext.description:
# âœ… Check ReversingLabs TitaniumCloud API quotas

## This action will execute a Logic App that will make calls to the TitaniumCloud TCA-9999 Quota API. The results will be loaded into your log analytics workspace under the RLTiCloudQuotas_CL table.

# âš ï¸ Please refresh the workbook after running this action to view updated data.

parameters.name: outdated_check
parameters.query:
RLTiCloudQuotas_CL
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *)
| extend timediff = datetime_diff('hour', TimeGenerated, now())
| extend outdated = iff(timediff <= -1, "true", "false")
| project outdated

content.json:
### Outdated Information
It has been over an hour since quotas were last checked. We recommend clicking the "check quotas" button to get the latest usage information.

### API Connection Error
There was an error during the most recent check for your API usage. Please check that your license is active and that you have configured the playbooks correctly.

content.query:
RLTiCloudQuotas_CL
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *)
| project TimeGenerated, Title="Quotas last checked"
| extend TimeGenerated = format_datetime(TimeGenerated, 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')
content.title: Timestamp

content.query:
RLTiCloudQuotas_CL
| where eventType_s == "connection_check"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *)
| extend errorMessage = ""
| extend errorMessage = column_ifexists("errorMessage_s", errorMessage)
| extend finalErrorMessage = strcat("Response code: ", errorMessage)
content.title: Connection status

content.query:
RLTiCloudQuotas_CL
| where eventType_s == "connection_check"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *)
content.title: API user

content.query:
let userDailyUsage = RLTiCloudQuotas_CL
| where TimeGenerated > startofday(now())
| where eventType_s == "user_daily_usage"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by product_s
| project product_s, numberOfQueries_d;
RLTiCloudQuotas_CL
| where TimeGenerated > startofday(now())
| where eventType_s == "company_quota_limits"
| where limit_type_s == "daily"
| where users_s contains "{ticloud_api_user}"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by products_s
| extend products = todynamic(products_s)
| mv-expand products
| project TimeGenerated, tostring(products), ["Limit Type"]=limit_type_s, ["Limit Exceeded"]=limit_exceeded_s, ["Limit"]=limit_d, ["Users"]=users_s
| join userDailyUsage on $left.products == $right.product_s
| project TimeGenerated, products, ["Limit Type"]= strcat("Limit type: ", ["Limit Type"]), ["Limit Exceeded"], ["# of queries used"]=numberOfQueries_d, ["Limit"], ["Users"]
| extend percentUsed = (["# of queries used"]/Limit)
| extend fullDetails = strcat(split(tostring(["# of queries used"]), ".")[0], " / ", split(tostring(Limit), ".")[0])
content.title: Summary of Daily Limit API usage
content.noDataMessage: No API usage found for today.

content.json: The metrics below represent the combined TitaniumCloud API usage for all users tied to your organization.

content.query:
RLTiCloudQuotas_CL
| where TimeGenerated > startofmonth(now())
| where eventType_s == "company_monthly_usage"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by eventType_s, product_s
| where product_s != "TCA-9999"
| project TimeGenerated, product_s, numberOfQueries_d, month_s
| order by numberOfQueries_d
content.title: Current Monthly Usage

content.query:
RLTiCloudQuotas_CL
| where eventType_s == "company_daily_usage"
| summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by date_s, product_s
| where product_s != "TCA-9999"
| project TimeGenerated, product_s, numberOfQueries_d,  date_s
| extend Date=todatetime(date_s)
content.title: Daily Usage - Last 30 days

content.json: # â˜ï¸ TitaniumCloud API Usage
You don't appear to be using any TitaniumCloud APIs!

## First time setup
Ensure that you have deployed the ReversingLabs-CheckQuota playbook. Next, enter the workbook advanced editor, then search for ```armActionContext```. In the ```path``` value, paste the ARM path of the ReversingLabs-CheckQuota playbook. There should be two (2) of these values that you will need to update.

Example: ```"path": "/subscriptions/<subscription_id>/resourceGroups/<resource_group_name>/providers/Microsoft.Logic/workflows/ReversingLabs-CheckQuota/triggers/manual/run?api-version=2016-06-01"```


Once the above is completed, click the "Check quotas" button below and refresh the workbook after a few minutes.

armActionContext.title: Check quota
armActionContext.description:
# âœ… Check ReversingLabs TitaniumCloud API quotas

## This action will execute a Logic App that will make calls to the TitaniumCloud TCA-9999 Quota API. The results will be loaded into your log analytics workspace under the RLTiCloudQuotas_CL table.

# âš ï¸ Please refresh the workbook after running this action to view updated data.
